{{Infobox officeholder |name = Ahmed Hassan Said |image = AhmedHSaid.jpg |office = [[Free Egyptians Party|Chairman of the Free Egyptians Party]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Free Egyptians Party elects chairman|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/05/11/free-egyptians-party-elects-chairman/|accessdate=14 May 2014}}</ref> |term_start = May 2013 |term_end = September 2014 |predecessor = ''Office created'' |successor = |office1 = Vice President of [[Al Ahly SC]]<ref>{{cite web|title=بالأرقام.. قائمة محمود طاهر تكتسح "المعلم" في انتخابات النادي الأهلي|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/news/details/419018|accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> |term_start1 = 28 April 2014 |term_end1 = 2018 |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|12|28|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] |nationality = [[Egypt]]ian |party = [[Free Egyptians Party]] |alma_mater = [[American University in Cairo]] |profession = [[Businessman]] }}
'''Ahmed Hassan Said''' is a prominent Egyptian businessman in the IT sector and has become a leading political figure as a result of the [[Arab Spring]] uprising and the ouster of former President [[Hosni Mubarak]]. Said was at [[Tahrir Square]] since the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] started.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ahmed Said interview on NDTV|url=//www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZLQyT1_uWwY|publisher=[[YouTube]]|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref>
Said was one of the founders of the [[Free Egyptians Party]] (FEP). A party that was founded in April 2011 and is backed by leading business, political, and cultural leaders. FEP supports the principles of a [[liberalism|liberal]], [[democracy|democratic]], and [[secular]] political order in post-Mubarak Egypt.
Said was the first President of FEP. He also played a key role in the creation of the [[Egyptian Bloc]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Liberals, leftists form new coalition; to contest elections under a unified roster.|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/liberals-leftists-form-new-coalition-to-contest-elections-under-a-unified-roster.html|newspaper=[[Daily News Egypt]]|date=15 August 2011|accessdate=24 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ahmed Said interview on Newsmax TV|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-FJyJ_g_vL0|publisher=Newsmax TV|accessdate=26 September 2011}}</ref> He won a seat in the [[parliamentary election]] of 28–29 November 2011. Said participated in FEP's political rally of 9 October 2011 among the [[Maspero demonstrations]] that led to the massacre of many protesters. He was injured and hospitalized as a result of the military's action against the demonstrators. He was also key in forming the [[National Salvation Front (Egypt)|National Salvation Front]] and was its secretary-general July 2013 to January 2014 after [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] stepped down from being the coordinator-general of the Front.<ref>[http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/Print/3486.aspx No one after] 23 July 2013. Retrieved 5 January 2015.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2014/01/05/secretary-general-of-the-national-salvation-front-resigns/|author=AbdelHalim H. AbdAllah|title=Secretary general of the National Salvation Front resigns|work=Daily News Egypt|date=5 January 2014|accessdate=5 January 2015}}</ref>
==Background== Ahmed Said was born in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]], on December 28, 1961, to Eng. Hassan Said and Faten Fathi. He has a younger brother, Hisham Said.
In 1979, Ahmed obtained his General Certificate of Education diploma from Dar El Tifl School in Cairo. In 1985, he received his bachelor's degree in Political Science from The [[American University in Cairo]] (AUC). At AUC Said was elected President of the [[Student Union]].
Ahmed showed signs of early talent in swimming. He was able to win the Open Championship of Egypt at the age of 15. He later dominated the 100m [[Butterfly stroke]] event on both the local Arab and African level from 1977 until 1984, when he stopped competing. His African record remained unbroken until 1987. His swimming career was crowned by representing Egypt at the [[1984 Summer Olympics]] in Los Angeles.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VLryd3w5yng</ref>
In 1988, he went on to earn an [[MSc]] in [[Public Policy]] from the [[London School of Economics]]. He completed his [[PhD]] from [[Cairo University]] in 2002.<ref>{{cite book|last=Said|first=Ahmed|title=The role of NGOs in the development of SFD ([[Social Fund for Development (Egypt)|Social Fund for Development]]) Projects in Egypt. PhD thesis.|year=2002|publisher=Department of Political Science, Faculty of Economics and Political Science, Cairo University}}</ref>
==Professional life== On the professional level, Ahmed has extensive experience in planning and management consultancy. His areas of expertise also include local government, decentralization and Management Information Systems Development. During his work with the Egyptian Cabinet from 1994-1998 he managed the national illiteracy project.
In 1997, along with his brother Hisham, a former [[IBM]] executive, Said founded the Global Brands Group, an IT company that has become one of Egypt's leading technology providers. The company partners with such major IT firms as [[Microsoft]], [[Dell]], [[Hewlett-Packard]], [[Avaya]], and others.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Brands Group|url=http://www.gbrands.com/}}</ref>
He is married to Nivert El Sherif whose great-uncle is the well-known Egyptian “Dean of Arabic Literature” Dr. [[Taha Hussein]]. They have two daughters and one son.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *AUC (28 June 2010) Ahmed Said, AUC Alumnus, speaks at the Eighty Seventh AUC Bachelor's Commencement. *[//www.youtube.com/watch?v=inbzkeIoyD4] *[//www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxj3NikvL2k]

علي دوبا | birth_date={{birth year and age|1933}} | birth_place=[[Qurfays]], [[Jableh District]], [[French Mandate of Syria|Syria]] | death_date= | age= | death_place= | occupation = Head of the [[Military Intelligence (Syria)|Military Intelligence]] (1974–2000) | rank=[[File:Syria-Feriq.jpg|30px]] [[Lt. General]] | nationality= [[Syrian people|Syrian]] | religion= [[Alawite]] | party = [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Syria Region|Syrian Regional Branch]] of the [[Ba'ath Party (Syrian-dominated faction)|Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party]] }} '''Ali Douba''' ({{lang-ar|علي دوبا}}) (b. 1933) is a former head of the [[Syria]]n [[Military Intelligence (Syria)|military intelligence]] and was a close adviser to the Syrian president [[Hafez al-Assad]].{{Cite web | title = Syria's Leaders | publisher =[[Council on Foreign Relations]] | url = http://www.cfr.org/syria/syrias-leaders/p9085 | first = Esther | last =Pan | date =10 March 2006 | accessdate =11 February 2011}} The military intelligence under Douba was the single most important security agency in Syria, handling security within the army, but also dealing with the general safeguarding of the regime.{{cite journal |last=Zisser |first=Eyal |title=The Succession Struggle in Damascus |journal=[[The Middle East Quarterly]]|volume=2 |date=September 1995 |pages=57–64|url=http://www.meforum.org/264/the-succession-struggle-in-damascus}} ==Early life== Douba was born to a small landowning family from the [[Alawite]] tribe of Matawira, in the village of [[Qurfays]] in the [[Jableh District]] south of [[Latakia]]. He joined the [[Ba'ath Party]] in the early 1950s while studying the Holy Land Secondary School in Latakia.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mbr-ZfU_uCoC&pg=PA240&dq=%22Ali+Duba%22&hl=en&ei=MQ9VTeHeJ4_qvQOXzL2uBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFIQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22Ali%20Duba%22&f=false|title=Syria's peasantry, the descendants of its lesser rural notables, and their politics|first=Hanna|last=Batatu|edition=Illustrated|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=1999|isbn=978-0-691-00254-5|page=240|authorlink=Hanna Batatu}} ==Career== Douba joined the [[Syrian Army]] in 1955 and became the deputy head of internal security in [[Damascus]] five years later. He served as [[military attaché]] at the Syrian embassy in [[Great Britain]] between 1964 and 1966, and in [[Bulgaria]] between 1967 and 1968. He returned to Syria and became the head of military intelligence for the [[Latakia]] region. In November 1970, he was appointed the head of military intelligence for the city of Damascus, where he supported [[Corrective Movement (Syria)|Hafez al-Assad's coup d'état]]. In 1971, he was made deputy to the head of military intelligence, [[Hikmat al-Shihabi]]. Three years later he was made head of this department. He was elected to the Central Committee of the [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Syria Region|Syrian Regional Branch]] of the [[Ba'ath Party (Syrian-dominated faction)|Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party]] in 1978, and promoted to general in 1981. Douba took part in suppressing the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] [[Hama massacre|revolt in Hama]] during February 1982. In December 1983, when President Hafez al-Assad was ill, Duba was a member of the committee responsible for governing the state in the interim. In 1985, the Syrian president put him in charge of the Lebanon dossier, along with al-Shihabi and [[Ghazi Kanaan]]. Douba was promoted to [[lieutenant general]] and appointed deputy chief of the General Staff in January 1993, in addition to his role as head of the military intelligence.{{cite book | last = Faure | first =Claude | authorlink = | title = Dictionary of the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Culture, History, and Politics | publisher = Macmillan Reference USA | isbn = 0-02-865977-5 | page = 109 | year = 2002}} In 1999 he was pushed aside by [[Bashar al-Assad]] over fears that he could be a rival for the presidency, and was made to retire in February 2000. He is still living in Syria. EU [[Council Regulation]] 36/2012 places him on a list of persons whose funds are frozen.http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2012:016:0001:0032:EN:PDF ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Duba, Ali}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:Syrian military personnel]] [[Category:Syrian Alawites]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Syria Region politicians]] [[Category:People from Latakia Governorate]] [[Category:People of the Islamic uprising in Syria]]

{{Infobox person | name = Alvin "Shipwreck" Kelly | image = Shipwreck kelly baltimore sun.JPG | alt = | caption = "Shipwreck" Kelly pole sitting in 1942 | birth_name = Aloysius Anthony Kelly | birth_date = {{Birth date|1893|05|11}} | birth_place = [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]], [[New York City]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1952|10|11|1893|05|11}} | death_place = [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]], New York City | nationality = American | other_names = Shipwreck Kelly | occupation = [[pole-sitting|pole sitter]] | known_for = }}
'''Aloysius Anthony Kelly''',<ref name="Sarasota" /> popularly known as '''Alvin "Shipwreck" Kelly''' (May 11, 1893<ref name="Burial record">{{cite web|title=Report of Internment, The Quartermaster General, Anthony Aloysius Kelly, DOB May 11, 1893, Date of Death, Oct. 11, 1952|url=http://interactive.ancestry.com/2590/40479_2321306652_0460-01820/2058074?backurl=http%3a%2f%2fsearch.ancestry.com%2fcgi-bin%2fsse.dll%3frank%3d1%26new%3d1%26MSAV%3d1%26msT%3d1%26gss%3dangs-g%26gsfn%3dAloysius%2bAnthony%26gsln%3dKelly%26gsln_x%3dXO%26msbdy%3d1885%26msbpn__ftp%3dNew%2bYork%2bCity%2b%28All%2bBoroughs%29%252c%2bNew%2bYork%252c%2bUSA%26msbpn%3d1652382%26msbpn_PInfo%3d6-%257c0%257c1652393%257c0%257c2%257c3244%257c35%257c1652382%257c0%257c0%257c0%257c%26msddy%3d1952%26cpxt%3d0%26catBucket%3drstp%26uidh%3dv64%26cp%3d0%26pcat%3dROOT_CATEGORY%26h%3d2058074%26recoff%3d7%2b8%2b9%26db%3dIntermentControlForms%26indiv%3d1%26ml_rpos%3d12&ssrc=&backlabel=ReturnRecord|website=Ancestry.com|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="NYTimes -death">{{Cite news|url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1952/10/12/84589484.pdf|title = Shipwreck Kelly Dies on Sidewalk|last = |first = |date = 12 October 1952|work = |accessdate = 14 December 2014|newspaper = The New York Times|agency = |quote = "Although the police gave his age as 67, he has written in newspaper articles and in a pamphlet found in his room that he was born on May 13, 1893, which would make him 59 years old."}}</ref><ref name="Abstract" /> [some accounts say 1885]<ref name="Toledo">{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2206&dat=19521012&id=OsgyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=C-wFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3397,6114670|title = 'Shipwreck' Kelly, 'Luckiest Fool,' Dies|last = |first = |date = 12 October 1952|work = |accessdate = 14 December 2014|newspaper = Miami News|agency = Associated Press|quote = "Clippings gave his age as 59, but police who inspected his papers said he was 67."}}</ref> – October 11, 1952<ref name="Sarasota"/><ref>Martin, Carol J. Dance Marathons: Performing American Culture Of The 1920s And 1930s. [[University Press of Mississippi]], 1994. {{ISBN|0878057013}}. Retrieved June 4, 2016.</ref>), was a [[Pole-sitting|pole sitter]] who achieved fame in the 1920s and 1930s, sitting for days at a time on elevated perches throughout the United States.
== Early life == Kelly was born in Manhattan's [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]] neighborhood. His mother died during childbirth and his father died before he was born. He ran away and went to sea at the age of 13, and changed his name to Alvin. In his early years he worked as a [[steelworker]], [[steeplejack]], [[high diver]], boxer and [[Body double|movie double]]. He was also a [[Pilot licensing and certification|licensed pilot]] who performed [[Stunt pilot|aerial stunts]].<ref name="Sarasota" /> He served as an [[Ensign (rank)|ensign]] in the U.S. [[Merchant Marine Reserve|Naval Auxiliary Reserve]] during [[World War I]], serving from May 1918 to September 1921.<ref name="Burial record"/><ref name="NYTimes -death" /> During the war he served on the [[USS Edgar F. Luckenbach (ID-4597)|USS ''Edgar F. Luckenbach'']].<ref name="Abstract">{{cite web|title=New York, Abstracts of World War I Military Service, 1917-1919, Aloysius Anthony Kelly|url=http://interactive.ancestry.com/3030/40808_1120704930_0807-00393/69828?backurl=http%3a%2f%2fsearch.ancestry.com%2fcgi-bin%2fsse.dll%3fgst%3d-6&ssrc=&backlabel=ReturnSearchResults|website=Ancestry.com|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref>
== Career == According to one account,Kelly climbed his first pole at the age of seven, and at nine he performed a "[[Velcro jumping|human fly]]" trick, climbing up the side of a building.<ref name="Sarasota" /> He is credited with popularizing the pole-sitting fad after sitting atop a flagpole in 1924, either in response to a dare from a friend <ref>Long, Mark A., and Jim Fee. ''Bad Fads.'' Toronto: ECW, 2002. p. 17 ''Ebrary.'' Web. 22 December 2011.</ref> or as a publicity stunt to draw customers to a [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] department store.<ref name="Pole position">Baker, Danny. "Shipwreck for ever in pole position." ''The Times'' (United Kingdom) 21 August 2002: ''Newspaper Source Plus.'' Web. 22 December 2011.</ref> In January of that year he sat on a pole for 13 hours and 13 minutes to publicize a movie.<ref name="Sarasota" />
In 1926, Kelly set a record by sitting atop a flagpole in [[St. Louis, Missouri]] for seven days and one hour; in June 1927, he planned to beat that record by sitting for eight days in [[Newark, New Jersey]].<ref name="Rooster">"Flagpole Rooster". ''Time'' 9.25 (20 June 1927): 12. ''Academic Search Premier.'' Web. 22 December 2011.</ref> He would end up sitting atop the Newark pole for twelve days,<ref name="Twelve">"Twelve Days". ''Time.'' 9.26 (27 June 1927): 11. ''Academic Search Premier.'' Web. 22 December 2011.</ref> and on a pole in [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]]'s [[Carlin's Park]] for 23 days in 1929.<ref name="Sarasota" /> In 1930 he set a world record by sitting on a flagpole on top of the [[Steel Pier]] in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]], {{convert|225|ft}} high, for 49 days and one hour.<ref name="Maeder - 1999" /><ref>{{Cite news|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vUoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA27&dq=shipwreck+kelly|title = Ozzie & Shipwreck|last = |first = |date = 4 October 1948|work = LIFE}}</ref>
At the height of his fame as a latter-day [[stylite]], he toured 28 cities, charging admission to people who wanted to stand on roofs to see his performance stunts. He also earned an income from [[Testimonial|endorsements]], personal appearances and books about his life. He called himself "the luckiest fool in the world." He once calculated that over two decades he spent 20,613 hours sitting on flagpoles, of which 210 were in sub-freezing weather and 1400 hours in the rain.<ref name="NYTimes -death" /><ref name="Maeder - 1999" /> In one 1927 stunt, he climbed on a pole on a speeding [[biplane]], sitting on a {{convert|12|in|cm|spell=in|adj=on}} iron [[:wikt:crossbar|crossbar]] as the plane flew {{convert|500|ft}} high. ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that "he didn't get around to hanging by one hand, as he promised he would."<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1927/11/11/94918572.pdf|title = Climbs a Flagpole on Speeding Airplane|last = |first = |date = 11 November 1927|work = The New York Times|accessdate = 14 December 2014}}</ref>
While pole sitting, Kelly was said to have subsisted mainly on [[coffee]] and [[cigarette]]s. He learned how to nap while sitting upright, and never was secured by more than a simple leg strap. He once claimed that he doesn't "take as many chances as a [[window cleaner]]." Journalist Jay Maeder wrote that "The newspapers were regularly full of pictures of Shipwreck Kelly, matter-of-factly brushing his teeth and shaving his face, hundreds of feet in the air."<ref name="Maeder - 1999" /> He said that he was able to sleep while pole sitting by putting his thumbs in holes in the pole shafts. If he swayed, the pain in his thumbs would force him to right himself without waking him up.<ref name="NYTimes -death" />
His career began to decline after the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929]], and in 1934 he was working as a [[gigolo]] at a [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] dance hall, [[Roseland Ballroom|Roseland]], then a [[Taxi dance hall|"dime a dance" hall]]. Journalist [[H. Allen Smith]] found him "wearing a [[tail coat]] and [[silk]] hat, sitting on a [[plush]] [[Divan (furniture)|divan]]." By then, Kelly said, 17 people were claiming to be him, because few people knew what he looked like.<ref name="Smith - 1934">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=H. Allen|authorlink1=H. Allen Smith|title=Shipwreck Kelly Tells All, Admits He's Just a Gigolo|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19340203&id=848cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v44EAAAAIBAJ&pg=2423,844546|accessdate=14 December 2014|work=The Pittsburgh Press|agency=United Press|date=3 February 1934}}</ref> In the 1930s there was less tolerance for such stunts, and police took a dim view of the disruption it caused. In 1935 he attempted to break his Atlantic City record by sitting on a pole in the [[Bronx]], but was aloft for less than a day before he was arrested as a public nuisance. He only climbed down from the pole after police threatened to cut it down.<ref name="NYTimes -death" /><ref name="Maeder - 1999" />
One of his last major public appearances was on October 13, 1939: Kelly celebrated National Donut Dunking Week by sitting on a pole atop the [[Chanin Building]] on East [[42nd Street (Manhattan)|42nd Street]] in Manhattan and eating 13 donuts dunked into a coffee cup and fed to him while he stood on his head.<ref name="Timeless">Romero, Librado. "Timeless". ''New York Times'' 29 September 2010: 24. ''Newspaper Source Plus.'' Web. 22 December 2011.</ref> But by then that kind of work had pretty much dried up, He served in the [[United States Merchant Marine]] during [[World War II]].<ref name="Maeder - 1999" />
Accounts vary as to how Kelly acquired his nickname. He claimed to have survived during his lifetime five [[shipwreck]]s, two airplane and three automobile accidents, and one train wreck, all without injury.<ref name="NYTimes -death" /> His wife told reporters that he was a survivor of the [[Sinking of the RMS Titanic|sinking of the RMS ''Titanic'']].<ref name="Rooster" /> However, there were only three ''Titanic'' survivors named Kelly and all were women, and "there is no reason to believe that he ever came near the ''Titanic''."<ref name="Titanic">{{cite web|title=Titanic Survivors|url=http://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-survivors/|website=Encyclopedia Titanica|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="Maeder - 1999">{{cite news|last1=Maeder|first1=Jay|title=The Guy in the Sky Shipwreck Kelly|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/guy-sky-shipwreck-kelly-article-1.850977|accessdate=14 December 2014|work=The Daily News|date=19 September 1999}}</ref> He is also said to have gained the nickname as a boxer,<ref name="Sarasota" /> because "he was so often adrift in the ring that the handle became inevitable."<ref name="Pole position" />
He was described in a 1939 article as a "stocky, blue-eyed, battered little Irishman" with "sparse red hair."<ref name="Spokesman Review 1939">{{cite news|title=Flagpole Champ Home for Game|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19391229&id=WChWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9uMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6831,4428016|accessdate=14 December 2014|work=The Spokesman-Review|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>
Kelly's last flagpole-sitting appearance was at an [[Orange, Texas]] event sponsored by the [[Lion's Club]] on October 4, 1952, one week before his death. Two [[heart attack]]s forced him to come down from the 65-foot pole, and the club refused to let him go back up. He retired as a result of the heart attacks, saying "This is it. I'm through."<ref name="AP -10-5-52">{{cite news|title=Heart Attack Keeps Sitter Down From Flag Pole|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4008676/retired_shortly_thereafter/|accessdate=10 January 2016|work=Waco Tribune-Herald|agency=Associated Press|date=October 5, 1952|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref><ref name=Star-10-7-52>{{cite news|title=Shipwreck Kelly Quits After 2 Heart Attacks On Top of 65-Foot Pole|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4008662/the_lincoln_star/|accessdate=10 January 2016|work=The Lincoln Star|agency=Associated Press|date=October 7, 1952|page=18|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref>
==Personal life== Kelly married an elevator operator, Frances Vivian Steele of Dallas, Texas,<ref name="NYTimes -death" /> whom he met while pole sitting.<ref name="Sarasota" /> They had a son, Alvin Kieran Kelly,<ref name="NYTimes -death" /> who became a laborer for the [[Clyde Beatty Circus]]. In June 1973, the son was killed at the age of 45 by an elephant during a performance in [[Tenafly, New Jersey]]. A female [[Asiatic elephant]] lifted him in the air and then put him down and stepped on his chest, crushing him to death before a horrified crowd.<ref name="Maeder - 1999" /><ref name="Killer animals">{{cite book|last1=Ricciuti|first1=Edward R.|title=Killer animals : shocking true stories of deadly conflicts|date=2003|publisher=Lyons Press|location=Guilford, Conn.|isbn=978-1585748686|pages=171–172|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RFIwg58DeLEC&pg=PA172}}</ref><ref name="Times - June 1973">{{cite news|title=Circus Helper Crushed to Death by Elephant He Was Handling|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1973/06/05/79860245.pdf|accessdate=14 December 2014|work=The New York Times|date=5 June 1973}}</ref>
==Death==
At the time of his death in October 1952, Kelly had become a "grizzled old man" – penniless and all but forgotten. He was by then a widower who had been on [[General Assistance|home relief]] for six months, and his son was in the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] overseas. He had been suffering from an [[cardiac asthma|asthmatic heart]] and [[Atherosclerosis|hardening of the arteries]].<ref name="NYTimes -death" /><ref name="Toledo" />
Kelly died on October 11, 1952 when he was struck by a car while walking on [[Manhattan]]'s West [[51st Street (Manhattan)|51st Street]],<ref name="NYTimes -death" /> near the [[boarding house|rooming house]] where he lived and not far from his birthplace.<ref name=alvin>Rasmussen, Frederick M. [http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-11-20/features/9911200442_1_flagpole-kelly-shipwreck "The original flagpole sitter."] [[The Baltimore Sun]], November 20, 1999. ''www.articles.baltimoresun.com.'' Retrieved May 17, 2015.</ref> For a time his body was unclaimed at the morgue,<ref name="Sarasota">[[United Press]]. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1787&dat=19521013&id=tuMcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vmQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4571,5934352 "Body of 'Shipwreck' Kelly Lies Unclaimed in Morgue."] [[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]], October 13, 1952. [[Google News Archive]]. Retrieved June 4, 2016.</ref> but he was buried at [[Long Island National Cemetery]] in [[Farmingdale, New York]].<ref name="Burial record"/>
Belongings found in Kelly's room included a [[duffel bag]] still packed with ropes and flagpole-sitting gear, "in case any fresh jobs came along."<ref name="Maeder - 1999" /> At the time of Kelly's death a [[:wikt:scrapbook|scrapbook]] of his exploits was under his arm. He had titled the scrapbook "The Luckiest Fool on Earth."<ref name="NYTimes -death" /><ref name=alvin />
== References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

{{Infobox person | name = | image = Ben Linder with Nicaraguan children.jpg | alt = | caption = Linder with Nicaraguan children | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1959|07|07}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1987|04|28|1959|07|07}} | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Engineer | known_for = Electrification work in rural Nicaragua, murdered while working on a hydroelectric facility near El Cuá Blood of Brothers, page 328; Kinzer }} '''Benjamin Ernest "Ben" Linder''' (July 7, 1959 – April 28, 1987), was an [[United States|American]] engineer. While working on a small [[hydroelectric dam]] in rural northern [[Nicaragua]] Linder was killed by the [[Contras]], a loose confederation of rebel groups funded by the U.S. government. Coming at a time when U.S. support for the Contras was already highly controversial, Linder's death made front-page headlines around the world and further polarized opinion in the United States. ==Biography== The [[California]]-born Linder graduated from [[Adams High School (Portland, Oregon)|Adams High School]] in [[Portland, Oregon]] in 1977. While in College at the [[University of Washington]], Linder enjoyed [[juggling]] and was often seen around [[Seattle]] riding a {{convert|5|to|6|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} [[unicycle]]. He graduated in 1983, with a degree in [[mechanical engineering]]. He left his Oregon home that summer and moved to [[Managua]], the capital of Nicaragua. Linder felt inspired by the 1979 [[Sandinista National Liberation Front|Sandinista]] revolution, and wanted to support its efforts to improve the lives of the country's poorest people. The [[Ronald Reagan|Reagan administration]], however, saw the Sandinistas as a beachhead of [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Communism]] in the [[Western Hemisphere]], and was determined to cripple the revolution. Beginning in 1981, the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] secretly trained, armed and supplied thousands of [[Contras|Contra]] rebels. A major element of the Contras' strategy was to launch attacks on government cooperatives, health clinics and power stations — the very things that most exemplified the improvements that had been brought about by the revolution. In 1986, Linder moved from Managua to [[El Cuá]], a village in the Nicaraguan war zone, where he helped form a team to build a hydroelectric plant to bring electricity to the town. While living in El Cuá, he participated in vaccination campaigns, using his talents as a clown, juggler, and unicyclist to entertain the local children, for whom he expressed great affection and concern. On 28 April 1987, Linder and two Nicaraguans were killed in a Contra ambush while traveling through the forest to scout out a construction site for a new dam for the nearby village of [[San José de Bocay]]. The [[autopsy]] showed that Linder had been wounded by a [[grenade]], then shot at point-blank range in the head. The two Nicaraguans — Sergio Hernández and Pablo Rosales — were also killed at close range. Linder was posthumously awarded the [[Courage of Conscience award]] [http://www.peaceabbey.org/awards/cocrecipientlist.html The Peace Abbey Courage of Conscience Recipients List] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207195509/http://www.peaceabbey.org/awards/cocrecipientlist.html |date=February 7, 2009 }} on September 26, 1992. ==Controversy== Linder's death quickly inflamed the already-polarized debate inside the United States, with opponents of U.S. policy decrying the use of taxpayers' dollars to finance the killing of an American citizen as well as thousands of Nicaraguan civilians. The administration fought back, with [[White House]] spokesman [[Marlin Fitzwater]] quoted in ''[[The New York Times]]'' as saying that U.S. citizens working in Nicaragua had "put themselves in harm's way". [[Assistant Secretary of State]] [[Elliott Abrams]], an ardent proponent of the Contra War, echoed that view, saying that Linder should have known better than to be in a combat zone. Linder's mother Elisabeth, in Nicaragua for her son's funeral, said,
My son was brutally murdered for bringing electricity to a few poor people in northern Nicaragua. He was murdered because he had a dream and because he had the courage to make that dream come true. ... Ben told me the first year that he was here, and this is a quote, "It's a wonderful feeling to work in a country where the government's first concern is for its people, for all of its people."Gary Handschumacher, "Mourn Ben Linder, Not His Killer: Ronald Reagan's Death Squads," ''Counterpunch,'' June 16, 2004.
During a Congressional hearing in May 1987, some defenders of U.S. policy in Nicaragua responded, launching personal attacks on Linder's family and other witnesses. The ''[[Village Voice]]'' reported one exchange between [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Congressman [[Connie Mack III|Connie Mack]] of [[Florida]] and Elisabeth Linder, who had just given emotional testimony about her son's work and motivations. Mack accused Mrs. Linder of using her grief "to politicize this situation", adding, ''"I don't want to be tough on you, but I really feel you have asked for it."'' [https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/opinion/abroad-at-home-the-most-cruel.html ABROAD AT HOME; 'The Most Cruel'] By Anthony Lewis, May 15, 1987 The death of Linder, coming as Congressional hearings investigated the [[Iran-Contra Affair]], fueled the debate in the U.S. over the covert war in Nicaragua. The next year, Congress refused to renew aid to the Contras. But the civil war, conscription into the army, the collapse of the economy, and the curtailment of [[civil liberties]] in the mid-1980s all combined to cause the defeat of the [[FSLN]] government in February 1990 elections. In July 1996, American journalist [[Paul Berman]] published an article in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' featuring an interview with a man who claimed to have killed Linder.See: Paul Berman, "In Search of Ben Linder's Killers," ''The New Yorker,'' vol. 72, no. 28 (Sept. 23, 1996), pp. 58-??. Linder's parents and their lawyers publicly denounced the article and disputed the veracity of the man Berman interviewed. In 2001 journalist [[Joan Kruckewitt]], who lived in Nicaragua from 1983 to 1991 and covered the war between the Sandinistas and the Contras for [[Citadel Media|ABC Radio]], wrote a book entitled ''The Death of Ben Linder'' giving a more sympathetic portrait of Linder's life, work, and death.See: Joan Kruckewitt, ''The Death of Ben Linder.'' Seven Stories Press 2001. The song "[[Fragile (song)|Fragile]]" on [[Sting (musician)|Sting]]'s 1987 album, ''[[...Nothing Like the Sun]]'', is a tribute to Ben Linder.[http://www.sting.com/discography/index/album/albumId/194/tagName/studio_albums "Sting: Fragile CD,"] www.sting.com/ Singer-songwriter Dean Stevens wrote and recorded "The Children Knew Ben" on his 1989 CD, Seeds, for Volcano Records. The 1990 book ''[[Animal Dreams]]'' by [[Barbara Kingsolver]] is also dedicated to his memory, as was the (now closed) Ben Linder Cafe in [[Leon, Nicaragua]], which was adorned with his photo and memories of his life's work. ==See also== *[[Witness for Peace]] *[[Bill Stewart (journalism)|Bill Stewart]], an [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] reporter killed along with his interpreter in Managua in 1979. *[[Brian Willson]], an American injured by a Naval Munitions train while protesting US arms shipments to Central America. ==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Héctor Perla, Jr., "Heirs of Sandino: The Nicaraguan Revolution and the U.S.-Nicaragua Solidarity Movement," ''Latin American Perspectives,'' vol. 36, no. 6 (Nov. 2009), pp. 80–100. {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox serial killer | name= Beverley Allitt | image= | caption= | birth_name=Beverley Gail Allitt | alias=The Angel of Death | birth_date={{birth date and age|1968|10|04|df=y}} | birth_place= [[Grantham]], [[Lincolnshire]], [[England]] | death_date= | death_place= | cause= | penalty=13 [[Life imprisonment|life sentences]], [[Murder|murder]], [[Attempted murder|attempted murder]], [[Grievous bodily harm|GBH]] | weapon=[[Insulin]] | victims= 13 (4 deaths) | beginyear=February 1991 | endyear=April 1991 | country=[[United Kingdom]] | motive=Attention due to [[Munchausen syndrome by proxy]] | apprehended=1991 }}
'''Beverley Gail Allitt''' (born 4 October 1968) is an [[England|English]] [[serial killer|serial child killer]] who was convicted of murdering four children, attempting to murder three other children, and causing [[grievous bodily harm]] to a further six.<ref>{{Cite news | title=The verdicts: Beverley Allitt | last=Katz | first=Ian | work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London| date=18 May 1993}}</ref> The crimes were committed over a period of 59 days between February and April 1991 in the children's ward at [[Grantham and Kesteven Hospital]], [[Lincolnshire]], where Allitt was employed as a [[Licensed practical nurse#United Kingdom|State Enrolled Nurse]].<ref>{{Cite news | title=Nurse 'only link to children's deaths' | work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London| date=16 February 1993}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title=Shadows of death fell across Ward 4 | last=Jenkins | first=Lin | work=[[The Times]] | location=London | date=18 May 1993}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title=Killings fed a craving for attention | last=Jenkins | first=Lin | work=[[The Times]] | location=London | date=18 May 1993}}</ref> She administered large doses of [[insulin]] to at least two victims and a large [[air embolism|air bubble]] was found in the body of another, but police were unable to establish how all the attacks were carried out.<ref>{{Cite news | title=Child murderer confesses at last | last=Foster | first=Jonathan | work=[[The Independent]] | location=London | date=15 October 1993}}</ref> In May 1993, at [[Nottingham Crown Court]], she received thirteen [[Life imprisonment|life sentences]] for the crimes. Mr. Justice Latham, sentencing, told Allitt that she was "a serious danger" to others and was unlikely ever to be considered safe enough to be released.<ref>{{Cite news | title=Allitt jailed 'with no prospect of release' | last=Weale | first=Sally | work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London | date=29 May 1993}}</ref> She is detained at [[Rampton Secure Hospital]] in [[Nottinghamshire]].<ref>{{Cite news | title=Warning signs about Allitt 'overlooked' | last=Foster | first=Jonathan | work=[[The Independent]] | location=London | date=2 February 1994}}</ref>
==Early life== Beverley Allitt was born on 4 October 1968 and grew up in the village of [[Corby Glen]], near the town of [[Grantham]]. She had two sisters and a brother. Her father, Richard, worked in an [[off-licence]], and her mother as a school cleaner. Allitt attended [[Charles Read Academy|Charles Read Secondary Modern School]], having failed the test to enter [[Kesteven and Grantham Girls' School]]. She would often volunteer for baby-sitting jobs and left school at the age of 16, taking a course in nursing at [[Grantham College]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/drawn-curtains-in-a-silent-village-the-beverly-allitt-case-on-friday-this-baby-killer-will-be-sentenced-for-26-ajkttacks-including-four-murders-what-do-they-make-of-it-all-back-home-2324732.html|title=Drawn curtains in a silent village: The Beverly Allitt case: on Friday|date=1993-05-22|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-09-24}}</ref><ref name="AskillSharpe2014">{{cite book|author1=John Askill|author2=Martyn Sharpe|title=Angel of Death: Killer Nurse Beverly Allitt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vB3dAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT84|date=7 January 2014|publisher=Michael OMara|isbn=978-1-78243-245-6|pages=84–}}</ref>
==Victims==
===Died=== *Liam Taylor (seven weeks old) – was admitted to the ward for a chest infection and was murdered on 21 February 1991. *Timothy Hardwick (eleven years old) – a boy with [[cerebral palsy]] who was admitted to the ward after having an [[epileptic seizure]]. He was murdered on 5 March 1991. *Becky Phillips (two months old) – admitted to the ward for [[gastroenteritis]] on 1 April 1991. She was administered an [[insulin]] overdose by Allitt and died at home two days later; her death was originally believed to have been [[cot death]]. *Claire Peck (fifteen months old) – admitted to the ward following an [[asthma attack]] on 22 April 1991. After being put on a [[ventilator]], she was left alone in Allitt's care for a short interval during which time she went into [[cardiac arrest]]. She was resuscitated but died after a second episode of cardiac arrest, again following a period when she was left alone with Allitt.
===Survived=== *Kayley Desmond (then one year old) – admitted to the ward for a chest infection. Allitt attempted to murder her on 8 March 1991 but the child was resuscitated and transferred to another hospital, where she recovered. *Paul Crampton (then five months old) – admitted to the ward for a chest infection on 20 March 1991. Allitt attempted to murder him with an insulin overdose on three occasions the day before he was transferred to another hospital, where he recovered. *Bradley Gibson (then five years old) – admitted to the ward for [[pneumonia]]. He suffered two cardiac arrests on 21 March 1991, due to Allitt administering insulin overdoses, before he was transferred to another hospital, where he recovered. * Michael Davidson (then six years old) – admitted to the ward for [[Surgery#Post-operative care|post-operative care]] following an operation to remove an [[air rifle]] pellet that he had been injured with in an accident. After being injected with insulin multiple times through a [[cannula]] on his hand, he suffered from [[cyanosis]] and fell unconscious before being stabilised by other doctors on the ward. He later made a full recovery. *Yik Hung Chan (also known as Henry, then two years old) – admitted to the ward following a fall on 21 March 1991. He suffered an oxygen desaturation attack before he was transferred to another hospital, where he recovered. *Katie Phillips (then two months old) – Becky's twin was admitted to the ward as a precaution following the death of her sister. She had to be resuscitated twice after unexplained [[apnoeic]] episodes (which were later found to be caused by insulin and [[potassium]] overdoses). Following the second time that she stopped breathing, she was transferred to another hospital but, by this time, had suffered permanent [[brain damage]], partial paralysis and partial blindness due to [[oxygen deprivation]]. Her parents had been so grateful for Allitt's care of Becky that they had asked her to be Katie's [[Godparent|godmother]]. In 1999 Katie was awarded £2.125 million, by Lincolnshire Health Authority, to pay for treatment and equipment for the rest of her life. Lincolnshire Health Authority did not accept liability, but did acknowledge that Katie was entitled to compensation.
==Trial and imprisonment== Allitt had attacked thirteen children, four fatally, over a 59-day period before she was brought up on charges for her crimes. It was only following the death of Peck that medical staff became suspicious of the number of cardiac arrests on the children's ward and police were called in.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/308/6924/287 |title=Murder in the NHS |accessdate=6 February 2007 |date=29 January 1994 |publisher=W J Appleyard}}</ref> It was found that Allitt was the only nurse on duty for all the attacks on the children and she also had access to the drugs.
Four of Allitt's victims had died. She was charged with four counts of murder, eleven counts of [[attempted murder]] and eleven counts of causing [[grievous bodily harm]]. Allitt entered pleas of not guilty to all charges.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hospital nurse denies killing babies with insulin injections|last=Murray|first=Ian|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=16 February 1993}}</ref> On 28 May 1993 she was found guilty on each charge and sentenced to thirteen concurrent terms of life imprisonment, which she is serving at [[Rampton Secure Hospital]] in [[Nottinghamshire]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Behind the scenes at Rampton|last=Robinson|first=Oonagh|work=[[Nottingham Evening Post]]|location=Nottingham|date=28 November 2011|page=12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/angels/beverly_allitt/6.html |title=Beverly Allitt: Suffer the Children |accessdate=6 February 2007 |date=10 May 2000 |publisher=[[The Crime Library]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208092708/http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/angels/beverly_allitt/6.html |archivedate=8 February 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 6 December 2007, Mr Justice [[Stanley Burnton]], sitting in the [[High Court of Justice]], [[London]], confirmed that Allitt must serve the original minimum sentence of thirty years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Serial killer nurse Allitt must serve 30 years|first=David|last=Batty|date=6 December 2007|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|accessdate=29 August 2013|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2007/dec/06/ukcrime.health}}</ref> It was reported that some families of Allitt's victims had previously mistakenly believed that her minimum [[tariff]] had been set at forty years.<ref>{{cite news|date=6 December 2007|title=Child killer Allitt's tariff set|work=[[BBC News]]|location=London|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lincolnshire/7130211.stm|accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref>
Allitt's motives have never been fully explained. According to one theory, she showed symptoms of [[factitious disorder]], also known as Munchausen syndrome or [[Munchausen syndrome by proxy]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/famous_criminal/8/the_arrest/1/Beverley_Allitt.htm |title=Famous Criminals: Beverley Allitt |accessdate=6 February 2007 |date=10 February 2005 |publisher=Crime & Investigation Network |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121201300/http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/famous_criminal/8/the_arrest/1/Beverley_Allitt.htm |archivedate=21 November 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> This controversial disorder is described as involving a pattern of [[Child abuse|abuse]] in which a perpetrator ascribes to, or physically falsifies illnesses in, someone under their care to attract attention to themselves.
==In popular culture== In 2005, the [[BBC]] made a dramatisation of the story, ''Angel of Death'', in which [[Charlie Brooks]] played Allitt.<ref>{{cite web|title=Angel of Death: The Beverly Allitt Story|url=http://crimedocumentary.com/angel-death-beverly-allitt-story-2005/|website=crimedocumentary.com|accessdate=14 October 2017}}</ref> Allitt's story was depicted in episodes of the [[true crime]] documentaries ''[[Crimes That Shook Great Britain]]'', ''Born To Kill?'', ''Evil Up Close'', and ''Nurses Who Kill''.<ref>[http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/shows/evil-up-close/episode-guide/evil-up-close-series-1]</ref>
==See also== *[[John Bodkin Adams]] *[[Leonard Arthur]] *[[Kristen Gilbert]] *[[Harold Shipman]] *[[Maxim Petrov]] *[[Michael Swango]] *[[Dorothea Waddingham]]
